title: [COMPLETED] 7/20 Ranked Disabled - Upgrading NA Game Server Hardware
body:
Hey all,

In the wee hours of the morning on July 20th at 4:00AM PDT, we’re going to disable ranked for about 4.5 hours in order to upgrade some hardware on the Game Servers in Chicago.  Servers are a bit different than normal gaming PC’s, but hardware still works the same way -- every piece of hardware has a shelf-life, and eventually it’ll degrade or stop working.  By pro-actively upgrading this hardware now, we can ensure the servers will remain stable in the future.

While we are switching out the hardware, we're also going to need to reroute connections to our game servers.  This is where we may encounter some issues with disconnects, which is why we are disabling ranked pre-emptively.

http://i.imgur.com/LC5FaF6.png

If you get into a ranked game before 4:00AM PDT, you will be allowed to finish the game; we just won’t allow new ranked games to start.

We’ll make sure to update everyone on the progress or if we hit any issues!

No, *performances* may not degrade, but that's not the point here. The hardware will just fail at some point. If you ever had a hard drive failure, you'll understand that. And if you had not, you're pretty lucky.

Hardware hasn't infinite life, and the point is to replace it before it is likely to fail.

If the hardware does fail at some point then it's more than likely an issue of failing to properly care for it. Consistent strain and overheating would be cause for concern when hardware does fail, understandably I know that the Servers can be under strain quite a bit, in fact it was made clear how much actual stress there was around mid-end season 4 a simple ddos attack on the servers cause it to be unplayable for many people not just in the US but worldwide. But that aside yes hardware can fail if the circumstances add up to its downfall, other than that normal maintenance and periodic checks should keep the hardware running way past its supposed expiration date.

You don't know what you're talking about. In Data Centers or Cloud infrastructure, for instance, it's so common to have hardware failures that you have to design your system assuming there will be one. Even if something has a 0.01% chance to break in one year, if you use 10,000 of them, you'll have one breaking per day.

"Maintenance and periodic checks" are no magic, stuff breaks with time, and you have to replace it once in a while. Preferably **before** it *actually* breaks...
